comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: John O'Neill was from Carlow. In the 1901 census, in Carlow, I see: ONeill James Accomodation Road Carlow 17 M Cycle Fitter ONeill Edward Accomodation Road Carlow 15 M Cycle Fitter census.nationalarchives.ie/search/results.jsp?census_year...

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: If he's the same John O Neill he was a Cumann na nGaedheal member of Seanad Éireann in 1925. He was elected to the Seanad at a by-election on 5 March 1925 but lost his seat in the 1925 Seanad election on 17 September 1925 His name appears ----with Cycle manufacturer as occupation---- towards the bottom of the list of 1925 Seanad election candidates..for Wicklow? en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Seanad_election,_1925 Pleasants Street ---OSI (1907)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
A Trove red herring from 1897 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/115473058
A NEW INVENTION FOR LADIES' BICYCLES. This great improvement for ladies' bicycles has been invented by Mr. Charles O'Neill, Civil Engineer, Sydney, for the purpose of changing the ungainly and indelicate back view of the lady cyclist to an easy, graceful, and "reposeful" appearance. The 'improvement' consists of a piece of basket-work, which can be easily and quickly attached to any bicycle below the saddle by silvered fittings, and makes the lady appear to be sitting comfortably in an arm-chair, and does away with the use of an additional skirt, or change of dress, whilst the mounting and dismounting are not in the slightest degree interfered with. A compartment in the basket-chair is for the reception of small articles, such as gloves, toilet requisites, &c, &c. We hope that the present ugly and abrupt appearance of lady cyclists will soon be a dream of the past, and instead we will admire the aesthetic lines of the new invention. The invention can be ornamented in various designs, and is sure to meet with the approval of all. ... ...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That writer would have had caniptions if he'd(?) ever encountered back views of ladies clad in lycra!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Also from the Weekly Irish Times of Saturday, 5 April 1913... O'Neill's Bicyles were sold into China, West Africa, Portugal, India, New Zealand, America (North and South). The enthusiastic journalist wrote:
It is interesting to note that at the long distance cycle race at the Olympic Games in Stockholm [1912] the only team all of whose members finished was the Irish team, two-thirds of whom were mounted on Lucania cycles.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: It was called the LUCANIA CYCLE FACTORY....The Pleasants Street premises was built in 1911. comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: That's a fine "High Lizzie or High Nelly" the lad is resting his hand on.  You can see the basketing/extra spokes coming from the rear mudguard to keep ladies dresses/skirts/frocks from getting snarled in the back wheel!
